sp.l: For ever lost to Yvor.
When next we meet; you may perhaps repent
Of your. Disdain.

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Oh, leave me not, in Anger!—
Have you no Pity, then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I learn from You.—
Guards, to her Tent, conduct the Princess.

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Stay:—
Oh, Stay!—
Hard-hearted Man!—He will not hear me.
Nowk, Yvor; now, are we compleatly wretched!—
That vengeful Woman!—Oh, my gathering Terrours!—
How to support my Anguish, unassisted!
Unbefriended!—destitute of Comfort!—
But, though my Fears, like rising Floods, prevail,
And my weak Heart, on every Side, assail;
Through all Distresses, Yvor, will I prove
Still true to Thee; unshaken in my Love.

sp.speaker: Valens.
sp.l: WHOM seek you, Idwall? The General?

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: You, Valens;—
And, to disclose a Secret, may deserve
Your kindest Thanks.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doubt not of your Friendship:
But, what fresh Instance of it?

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: In your Love,
Your dearest Interest, am I come to serve you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas, my Friend!—Would it might be!—But, say:
How can'st thou serve me, in my Love?

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: Know then;
The Queen, enraged at the Demand of Vanoc,
Resolves to claim your Captive from you:—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: The Princess, for her Prisoner!—This obtain'd;
I fear the Event.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It strikes my Soul with Horrour!

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: She is too young, too good, too innocent,
To suffer: And Cartismand too far provok'd,—
To treat her kindly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Oh, the very Fright,
Were Gwendolen to know it, would be fatal,
Thou dost deserve my best of Thanks.

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will preserve her: With my Life, will I
Preserve the charming Maid!—Though still, I live
Depriv'd of Hope; abandon'd to Despair!

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: For Her, Compassion pleads, as strong as Love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou art a worthy Soldier.

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: But, the Queen
May come:—I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Adieu.
Alas;
Where, now, are my Resolves!—Do what I can,
My Tenderness prevails.—O, Gwendolen;
How exquisite art thou!—Perfection all!—
Nor can I blame thy Love.—Too happy Yvor!
How could I send her hence, oppress'd with Sorrow?—
Severest Proof of Fondness!—To her Tent,
This Instant will I hasten: Ask Forgiveness;
Asswage her Grief, and dissipate her Fears.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Let me not, Valens, hinder your Occasions.—
My Business is to Didius.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In his Absence
May Valens be intrusted?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: My Request,
Though small in Consequence, were bettertold
To Him.—Yet, you may hear it.—But I fear,
Your Heart may misinterpret my Intentions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then, Madam, were it kind to disabuse me.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Yet, why do I suppose, you should not wish,
The Princess were committed to my Care?—
Didius, I know, will not refuse it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Madam,
The General may think, his Captive as secure,
If she continues under his Protection.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: But, she is here, a Stranger; among Men;
Companionless; and full of Virgin Fears.
My Tent would be her Home.—I only ask,
What Decency requires.—It is my Duty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What Decency requires, shall not be wanting.
Her Women, her Attendants, shall have free Access.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: I should promote Your Love; watch every Season;
And teach her to forget all Thoughts of Yvor.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I read your Purpose, through the thin Disguize.
Is Cartismand no better known?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: How, Tribune!—
Does your malicious Thought pervert my Meaning?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do I not know your Hatred to the Princess?—
The pitying Gods preserve her from Your Mercy!

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Presumptuous Man; thus to arraign my Goodness!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Was I not Witness to your cruel Usage?
When with submissive Gentleness, she bore
(Beneath her Father's Eye) your bitter Scorn;
Stifled her Griefs; hid all your blame in Smiles;
And interceded for the Wrongs she suffer'd.
And would you, now, resume your Tyranny;
Redouble every Anguish in her Soul;
And, through the harmless Daughter, wound the Father?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Peace, Traytor; peace!—The General shall know
Thy secret Dealings; thy dishonest Love.
Thou would'st for Gwendolen betray thy Countrey.
Thou hast, this very Day, combin'd with Vanoc:
Hast sold us: I perceive it.—But thy Life
Shall answer for the Treason!—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your Displeasure,
Your Suspicions concern me not.—To you
I might appeal, to every Roman here,
To every Briton, to acquit my Faith,
My Loyalty; unblemish'd by my Love.
I own, it was with Pain, I could prefer
My Duty to my Passion; to such Charms!—
But, in my early Youth, have I been taught,
The Love, a brave Man to his Countrey owes,
Should triumph over every sond Endearment.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Resign the Princess then:—And stand acquitted.
Yours is a thin Disguize; a Boast of Vertue;
While in your Love, you meditate our Ruin.—
But why, regardless of my Dignity,
Do I waste Words? When Didius can command;
Can check your Insolence.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are a Queen
Of high Descent: High seated, once, in Power;
And join'd in Wedlock, to a noble Prince.
That you are, now, abandon'd by your Subjects,
The People's Scorn; is not through our Demerits.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Speak on! And give full Proof, perfidious Wretch,
Of thy Adherence to the Foes of Claudius.
Declare thy smother'd Treason.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes; my Heart
Did ever disapprove your rash Attempt,—
That you had never reign'd, or reign'd more vertuous!—
What have I lost; what suffer'd by your Crime!
Accuse My Love!—Accuse your own Dishonour,
The Cause of all this War: A War to us,
Innlorious.—What could Vanoc less? Or, how
Can He forgive?—My sharp Despair
Will have its Vent.—Was not your Vellocad,
Your Paramour, your Infamy,—my Curse!—
That Man of Dress, the Servant of your Lord?
A Prince of such rare Qualities! So eminent!—
A juster Prince there lives not!—Nor more injur'd▪

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Audacious Roman!—Thy unruly Tongue
Be thy Accuser.—It is evident,
What made you fly; to whom you left the Field;
To whom you gave a Victory, so cheap!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Opprobrious Woman!—What is your Reproach?
Your Praise▪ alas! was never my Ambition.
Even all your Merit, howe'er confess'd by Claudius,
Turns to Disgrace on You.—One Prince betray'd;
And one dishonour'd: Both of high Renown;
Unmatch'd in British Story; have been the Sport
Of Cartismand, grown wanton in her Power.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Have done!—No farther urge me, on thy Life!—
O I could rend my Heart!—Do any Thing!—
So low am I declin'd; a Tribune's Scorn!
The Mock of Underlings!—My shameful Tears!—
But I will have the Prisoner; yes, I will!—
Or, woe upon you all!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Come General; Come:—
Avenge an injur'd Woman!—Right a Queen!

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: What new Disturbance, Madam?—More Suspicions!

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Abusive Treason utter'd! Spoke aloud!—
Your Tribune, there, betrays us Both!—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Injurious Rage!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: He leagues with Vanoc: Sells us for his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Valens, explain this Tumult of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: To him do you appeal?—

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Inform me, Tribune.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She comes, Sir, to demand your Captive from you.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: My Subject, Didius:—Is she not?

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: My Hostage, Cartismand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her Life would not be safe, could She obtain her.

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Madam, if this disturbs you; cool, at leisure.
I am to answer for the Princess.—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Oh,
My Distraction!—Are You smitten too?—
A Blight upon her Charms!—Now I perceive,
(Too late, alas!) I live amongst my Foes;
Or, with Allies, too powerful to be just.—
I am controll'd! A Bond-slave!—Perish first!—
Such Treatment, from the Men, I sav'd!—Endure it?—No!—
Rather will I submit to Vanoc's Vengeance;
And make my Ruin fatal to the Romans!

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Centurion, there!—Haste to the Captive Princess.—
Attend her hither.—Go,—return,—with Speed.
Valens, We have no Time for Counsel.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir!—

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Vanoc, and Yvor, with united Powers,
Bear (like a Tide) upon our Camp.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I fear'd
Some Enterprize: Though, not so sudden.—See,
The Princess.

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: O General! O Valens!—
What means this hasty Message to me?—Say,—
Am I deliver'd, then, to Cartismand?

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: In this Pavilion, Madam, guarded from Her,
Shall you remain; secure in my Protection.
Scarce have I Time to say; your Father, now,
Attempts our Mounds.—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: O Heaven!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Be not alarm'd.—
The General is tender of your Safety.

sp.speaker: Did.
sp.l: Keep a strict Watch, Centurion. On your Life,
Forbid all Entrance here; till we return.—
Princess, compose your Fears.—Come, Tribune; to our Posts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It grieves me, Gwendolen, to leave you thus;
Though here I leave you, unexpos'd to Danger.!
Forgive me, Princess:—Pity my Offence.
When I return, whatever Pangs I suffer,
You shall be happy.—Even Yvor shall confess,
Your Eyes ne'er kindled up a brighter Flame.
Unhappy, that I am.—My Cares now take
A different Cast; and fright me with new Terrors.—
O Yvor!—O, my Father!—Who can tell,
If ever we shall meet, in Life?—When You are slain;
In vain, am I preserv'd from Cartismand.—
You are not Proof against the Javelin's Point:
Nor I, against the Fears,—perhaps the Woes,—
The killing Woes of this uncertain Hour.—
Oh, 'tis begun!—The Roman Trumpet sounds!—
Again, the Signal ecchoes!—Louder still!—
My beating Heart!—Now it boads Wounds and Death.—
Let me be gone!—Oh, why am I confin'd?—
And, yet amidst the Battel, what can I!—
Can these defenseless Tears!—The distant Din
I hear confus'd!—That I cou'd be inform'd!—
But, oh, forbear!—I dread, alas, to know my Fate.—
What wafting Noise?—The British shouts!—Again!—
The Shouts of Victory!—Transporting Tumult!—
'Tis not Delusion?—Yet; Another Peal!—
Auspicious Token!—My Deliverance comes!
And thou, Adrasté, dost regard my Vows!—
What Clash of Weapons?—O defend them now!—
It is the Prince;—it is the King:—Or Both.—
Give way;—resist not, Romans!—Let me meet—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Yes; we are met!—And, in Despight of Valens,

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Heaven shield me!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: No Delay.—You must with me.

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Oh, whither must I?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Hence.—Our Hostage now!—
My Men shall guard you,:—better than the Romans.—
Vance is Master of the Camp.—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: One Moment hear me!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: We must away.—And now, thy boasted Sire.
Shall, soon, resign my Crown; or, thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: I never did offend

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: My Chariot waits.—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Hark!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: My Destruction!—Vanoc comes upon me!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Most timely Rescue!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Death to Thee!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: O spare▪
My Life!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: I will sequre my Vengeance!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Mercy!—
Help;—speedy Help!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Thus, Vanoc, to Thy Heart,
I drive the Poignard.—Thus, I brave thy Fury!

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Oh,—it is done!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Once more, my Gwendolen,
Receive me!—Take me to thy Arms!—Tumultuous Joy!—
We, never more, will part!—The King is safe:—
And thou, my Fair, art Yvor's Bride, again!

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: O, Yvor; O!—support me.—I grow faint.—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Distracting Sight!—Blood, on thy Bosom!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Inward,
I bleed.—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Where?—When?—How?—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: See, the murdering Queen!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: O, my disorder'd Senses?—Can it be!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: E'er you could force your Entrance,—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Accursed Woman!—Bane of Innocence!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Remember Vellocad!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Most cruel Savage!—
But;—Vanoc shall award thy Doom.—My Gwendolen!—
How fares my Love!—My dearest Life!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: The Sight
Of You delights,—and pains, my wounded Heart.—
Fain would I live!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Thou shalt live.—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: I cannot bear
To think of—parting from you.

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Name it not!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Relentless Fate! I feel the Stroke of Death!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Oh, thy Cheek turns pale!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: We are to live again.—Continue mine.—
Through every Life we pass,—let me be Yours.

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: O, ever!—Ever mine!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Sweet,—pleasing Hope!—
No Jealousy did ever interrupt our Love:—
Nor shall it yield to Death!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: My Agony!—
Thy Eye-Beams fade!—Oh, Gwendolen!—

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: My Prince!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Revive!—What Hope?—I cannot live without thee!

sp.speaker: Gwend.
sp.l: Live, for our Father's Sake:—And, do not grieve,—
Too much.—One Look!—O Yvor!—My Desire!—
My first,—my latest Love!—a while—farewel.

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Despair and Death!—Quite Speechless!—O, Distraction!—
Here will I fix:—Thus o'er thy dear Remains,
For ever weep;—and waste out Life, in wailing.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: O, where! Where is my Child? My Gwendolen?—
The Purchase of our Victory!—O, Horrour!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Bend thy stern Brow on Me!—I did the Deed!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Perdition on thee!—But, I stay my Hand!—
Speak, Yvor!—Oh, my Daughter!—Dead!—
Breathless, and pale!—O, most accomplish'd Mischief!—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Come, Alan; come.—See, there!—See my Distress!
Thy Master's Woe!—Behold the bloody Tygress!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Rave on!—My Vengeance is compleat!—
Live wretched!
Reign on, in Sorrow!—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: O, thy Misery
Will I prolong; and vary it through Life!—

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Hadst thou been more forgiving;—I had been
Less cruel.—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Wickedness! Barbarian! Monster!—
What had She done, alas?—Sweet Innocence!—
She would have interceded for thy Crimes.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Too well I knew the Purpose of thy Soul!—
Didst thou believe I would submit?—Resign my Crown?—
Or, that Thou, only, hadst the Power to punish?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Yet, I will punish;—meditate strange Torments!—
Then, give thee to the Justice of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: Thus, Vanoc, do I mock thy treasur'd Rage.—
My Heart springs forward, to the Dagger's Point.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Quick!—Wrest it from her!—Drag her hence to Chains.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.l: There needs no second Stroke.—
Adieu, rash Man!—My Woes are at an End:—
Thine but begun;—and lasting, as thy Life!—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Lasting, indeed! That thou hadst been less Guilty!—
My Shame not publick!—And more just the Romans!—
That my Resentment might have been appeas'd!—
O, Yvor, Prince!—Sad Partner in my Woe!—

sp.speaker: Alan.
sp.l: Auspicious Morning!—Fatal Close of Day!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Turn here thy streaming Eyes; O, Yvor, turn;
And mingle Tears with mine!—

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Most irksome Life!—But, what is Life to Me?—
My Sword shall end my Cares,—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Forbear, my Son!—
Already my Affliction is too heavy.

sp.speaker: Yvor.
sp.l: Not die?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Leave that false Vertue to the Romans.—
Our Injuries, my Daughter's Fate, our Countrey's Cause,
Bid us to live.—We must not throw off Life;—
But lay it down; when Heaven appoints us Rest.
Just Gods!—If my Resentments be too strong;
Or, over-rigid to compensate Wrong:—
Severely you my rash Offence chastise;—
Bereft, in Gwendolen, of All, I prize!
